description.narrative: Institutional strengthening for Bolivia's National Office for Standards and Quality

Standarder är marknadsdrivna och utgör ofta nyckelfrågor i revidering av nationell lagstiftning och reglering av handelsfrågor. De är i många fall även avgörande för att komma in på en regional eller internationell marknad i en globaliserad värld där handel sker över nationsgränser. Erfarenhet visar att användandet av internationella standarder kan bidra till att ett land eller ett företag kan få tillgång till nya marknader och öka sin export, då det garanterar en viss kvalitet etc och därmed bidra till ekonomisk utveckling. Studier visar att då länder som exporterar använder internationella standarder har det en positiv effekt på exporten. Samtidigt kan standarder vara hinder för ett lands ekonomi, om landet inte har kapacitet att påverka utvecklingen av internationella standarder och inte heller att implementera dem på nationell nivå.
Systerorganisationerna Swedish Standards Institute (SIS) och IBNORCA (Instituto Boliviano de Normalzación y Calidad) har utvecklat ett projektförslag som har som syfte att stärka IBNORCAs kapacitet gällande standardisering och implementering av standarder i Bolivia. Projektet ska också öka lokala parters engagemang i såväl nationella som internationella standardiseringsfrågor via ISO. Institutionsstärkande erfarenhetsutbyte mellan SIS och IBNORCA planeras likaså. Fokus ska särskilt ligga på standardisering inom vatten- och sanitetssektorn. Den föreslagna insatsen omfattar perioden 2017 – 2020 och har en budget på 20 MSEK.

participating-org.narrative: SIS/Swedish Standards Institute/Svenska institutet för standarder

tag.narrative: 17.9 - Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the Sustainable Development Goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.

17.9 - Öka det internationella stödet för genomförande av effektiv och riktad kapacitetsuppbyggnad i utvecklingsländerna till stöd för nationella planer för att genomföra alla målen för hållbar utveckling, inklusive genom samarbete nord–syd och syd–syd samt trepartssamarbete.

6.3 - By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.

6.3 - Till 2030 förbättra vattenkvaliteten genom att minska föroreningar, stoppa dumpning och minimera utsläpp av farliga kemikalier och material, halvera andelen obehandlat avloppsvatten och väsentligt öka återvinningen och en säker återanvändning globalt.

6.a - By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.

6.a - Till 2030 utöka det internationella samarbetet och stödet för kapacitetsuppbyggnad till utvecklingsländerna inom vatten- och sanitetsrelaterade verksamheter och program, inklusive genom tekniker för vatteninsamling, avsaltning, vatteneffektivitet, rening av avloppsvatten, återvinning och återanvändning.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The project has already reached the set goals regarding most indicators. Two main objectives have essentially already been reached. That is full membership of ISO allowing Bolivia to now influence the development of international water and non-water standards and the development and operationalization of a digital distribution and management system that, e.g., allows for the sales of standards and operating IBNORCA in a more efficient manner. Thanks to the membership, IBNORCA has been able to join additional ISO committees such as one more ISO water committee and provide comments on one ISO water standard under development. The project has also allowed for the initiation of various strategic co-operations with national standardization bodies in other countries. More work is needed to strengthen the individual and institutional capacity in the standardization process, especially regarding the international standardization work and becoming financially sustainable The mirror committee setup in Bolivia in the water area has gained a lot of traction. This traction has been maintained under 2019 and the committee has been divided into the following subcommittees to handle the workflow: -Water reuse, Water services Sludge handling and Industrial wastewater A matrix with 21 water standards that the committee will focus on has been developed, and four out of these standards have been nationally adopted. The timeframe for the matrix is 2019 to 2021.The key to the project is the adoption and implementation of these standards. One of the non-ISO standards included in the matrix is based on the EU water directive (i.e. stating legal requirements on effluent parameters for wastewater), and MMAyA has stated that they would consider this standard as a reference in a new regulation that complements the environmental law. This would have a profound impact on the water sector in Bolivia. In May, a workshop to discuss with stakeholders on the importance of using water in an efficient way, reducing water consumption and possible technologies for water treatment was held (activity 3.1.10). This in order to provide support for the necessity and feasibility of implementing more sophisticated and stringent standards being developed in Bolivia. Alternatives for wastewater technologies were described. A Swedish water expert and national speakers presented different wastewater treatment technologies from different points of view. One Bolivian case was presented by Aguatuya regarding wastewater treatment for irrigation. The project has over time built up is enough buy-in and knowledge among stakeholders for the project to focus on building capacity on specific water standards and the implementation of these. Getting the regulators involved in the development and adoption of standards is key in order to reach a greater impact and adpot for example the standard based on the EU water directive. Progress has been made both regarding increased engagement with government agencies to influence regulatory frameworks related to water standards, and development of criteria, operational procedures, and conformity assessment schemes. However, much work remains to assure that regulators take full advantage of the possibilities related to the work with water standards. One problem is the perceived higher costs that would come with more stringent regulations in the water sector and how these costs should be financed. Hence, the project is reliant on political decisions for the long-term objective to be fully realized. This is an area that needs further attention and that has been set back due to political unrest and changes in government.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
